comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: I believe that this photograph was taken on what is today called Queenscliff beach.  North Head reserve, Manly is the promontary at right background with a glimpse of the South Head of Sydney Harbour to the left of and behind North Head.

comment._content: Congratulations! This is a wonderful shot! You are invited to post it to: artland

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy] I reckon it is Coogee! Field trip and beachcomb to both locations required! I think the title is WRONG too. Using the excellent new Zoom at the Persistent URL, I get this: " 'BY THE SALT SEAWATER No.'2' . 3 [?] H.KING, PHOTr. SYDNEY. " Sea also PhM blog for reference to a popular song - www.powerhousemuseum.com/imageservices/index.php/2010/04/...

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] It could be Coogee. Before and around the turn of 1900 there were donkey rides on both beaches. King and Kerry of the Tyrrell photographic collection both photographed Manly, Coogee and their beaches. Even Phillips photographed Manly and Manly beach. However I spent five years working on the Manly beachfront and this view looks like the promontary of North Head to me. Here's another view from a different angle: from.ph/28691 www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2363496110/ I am not so well acquainted with Coogee so admit I am unable to compare and contrast accurrately. I'm happy to be proved wrong and often am.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: you can't see any of south head from queenscliff beach.  It looks like a reef there.  It could be long reef,  newport,  or coogee.  The bay looks too big to be coogee.  It could also be maroubra.
